pitrou commented on issue #3414: ARROW-4274: [C++][Gandiva] split decimal into two parts
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3414#issuecomment-456419965
 
 
   I'm a bit skeptical about the whole approach. This introduces some maintenance cost, but what do we gain from it? In the future, there'll probably be other code that will need similar massaging to avoid referencing the standard C++ library from compiled IR.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

pravindra commented on issue #3414: ARROW-4274: [C++][Gandiva] split decimal into two parts
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3414#issuecomment-456430024
 
 
   > I'm a bit skeptical about the whole approach. This introduces some maintenance cost, but what do we gain from it?
   
   Without this, we had to do 
   
   - special work for java (add a dependency on jna), 
   - special work for python 3.x (add RT_GLOBAL flag). 
   - it doesn't work for python 2.x.
   - it doesn't work when libstdc++ is statically linked. Can't export symbols because the symbols  can conflicts with other versions of the c++ runtime libraries. And, doesn't work without exporting the symbols ..
   
   Once I separated out the decimal implementations, it works seamlessly in all of the above cases.
   
    > In the future, there'll probably be other code that will need similar massaging to avoid referencing the standard C++ library from compiled IR.
   
   Agree. in such cases, we have two alternatives.
   
   1. split into IR-friendly and non-IR friendly files, (or)
   2. wrap it inside a gandiva fn and export it (AddGlobalMappingForFunc).
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

pitrou commented on issue #3414: ARROW-4274: [C++][Gandiva] split decimal into two parts
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3414#issuecomment-456434701
 
 
   For me the maintenance cost of this split is clearly higher than the cost of the two small Python and Java hacks. The base + derived class split is not really driven by semantics, and this is also introducing an additional `DecimalStatus`.
   
   As for the other issues:
   * Python 2 is essentially a legacy platform, so I don't think we should make it a priority to have Gandiva work with Python 2
   * the static libstdc++ issue is unfortunate, but I'm not sure how common it is either; when does it come out?
   
   > wrap it inside a gandiva fn and export it (AddGlobalMappingForFunc).
   
   Would it work to do this for Decimal?
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

pravindra commented on issue #3414: ARROW-4274: [C++][Gandiva] split decimal into two parts
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3414#issuecomment-456439114
 
 
   > The base + derived class split is not really driven by semantics, and this is also introducing an 
   > additional DecimalStatus
   
   agree. but, I couldn't come up with a better alternative :-(.
   
   > the static libstdc++ issue is unfortunate, but I'm not sure how common it is either; when does it come out?
   
   we use this for dremio. we build the gandiva library with statically linked stdc++ (and boost) on an OS with a sufficiently old libc (we are are using ubuntu 14), add the resulting .so to the java jar, and use it on all other linux platforms (ubuntu 14/16, cent-os 6/7, suse, RHEL ..)
   
   > Would it work to do this for Decimal?
   
   I could have done this if gandiva was the only user of Decimal128. but, we use the same file for both arrow and gandiva.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3414#issuecomment-456439114
 
 
   > The base + derived class split is not really driven by semantics, and this is also introducing an 
   > additional DecimalStatus
   
   agree. but, I couldn't come up with a better alternative :-(.
   
   > the static libstdc++ issue is unfortunate, but I'm not sure how common it is either; when does it come out?
   
   we use this for dremio. we build the gandiva library with statically linked stdc++ (and boost) on an OS with a sufficiently old libc (we are are using ubuntu 14), add the resulting .so to the java jar, and use it on all other linux platforms (ubuntu 14/16, cent-os 7, suse, RHEL ..)
   
   > Would it work to do this for Decimal?
   
   I could have done this if gandiva was the only user of Decimal128. but, we use the same file for both arrow and gandiva.

+
+#define ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(expr) ((void)(expr))
+
+#define DCHECK(condition) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(condition)
+#define DCHECK_OK(status) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(status)
+#define DCHECK_EQ(val1, val2) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1)
+#define DCHECK_NE(val1, val2) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1)
+#define DCHECK_LE(val1, val2) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1)
+#define DCHECK_LT(val1, val2) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1)
+#define DCHECK_GE(val1, val2) ARROW_IGNORE_EXPR(val1)

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
With the decimal changes, there can be cpp calls from the IR code. The symbols for these  need to be visible in the gandiva cpp library. but, the jni library makes visible only a limited set of symbols from gandiva (the ones specified in src/gandiva/jni/symbols.map).

This breaks  if the jni library links with the static-libstdc++ (dremio builds the gandiva binary with stdc++ statically linked) due to two reasons
 # The cpp symbols like std::ios_base::init are not exported via symbols.map. This causes LLVM to complain that there is are unresolved symbols.
 # Also, there is a problem with exceptions (string_view.hpp can throw exceptions) - This also causes LLVM to complain that unwindResume is unresolved.
fields.summary: [Gandiva] static jni library broken after decimal changes
